description: Numbers n such that (10^n + 1)/11 is a prime.
comments: The a(10) to a(11) gap represents the largest relative gap seen so far in searching repunits with bases between -12 and 12. On average, there should have been 4 more primes added to this sequence by a(11), instead of just 1. - _Paul Bourdelais_, Feb 11 2010
references: J. Brillhart et al., Factorizations of b^n +- 1. Contemporary Mathematics, Vol. 22, Amer. Math. Soc., Providence, RI, 2nd edition, 1985; and later supplements.
N. J. A. Sloane, A Handbook of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1973 (includes this sequence).
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: J. Brillhart, Letter to N. J. A. Sloane, Aug 08 1970
J. Brillhart et al., Factorizations of b^n +- 1, Contemporary Mathematics, Vol. 22, Amer. Math. Soc., Providence, RI, 3rd edition, 2002.
H. Dubner and T. Granlund, Primes of the Form (b^n+1)/(b+1), J. Integer Sequences, 3 (2000), #P00.2.7.
H. Lifchitz, Mersenne and Fermat primes field
S. S. Wagstaff, Jr., The Cunningham Project
mathematica: lst={};Do[If[PrimeQ[(10^n+1)/11], AppendTo[lst, n]], {n, 0, 10^4}];lst (* _Vladimir Joseph Stephan Orlovsky_, Sep 10 2008 *)
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
extensions: a(11) corresponds to a probable prime discovered by _Paul Bourdelais_, Feb 11 2010
